body.head.byline: By GINA MARANTO; Gina Maranto is a science journalist who has written on environmental issues and reported on the Biosphere II project.

block.p: Expanding on the much-debated Gaia hypothesis of the British atmospheric chemist James Lovelock - which holds that the globe and life on it constitute a superorganism engaged in maintaining the conditions necessary to its own survival - Dorion Sagan in this slim volume puts forward his view that the Earth is in the process of re-creating itself. Mr. Sagan, who is the co-author, with the biologist Lynn Margulis, of ''Microcosmos,'' posits that human beings are '' 'genitals' . . . the planetary counterpart to reproductive organs,'' and that they have, primarily through the development of industrial technology, become ''incestuously involved'' with Mother Earth.

In a bizarre act of reproduction, we, the planet's gonads, have begun to construct hermetically sealed, self-sustaining ecological enclosures. (The largest conceived to date is the two-acre Biosphere II, a building in the Arizona desert north of Tucson). These so-called biospheres constitute the first stages of the Earth's embryonic differentiation, says the author, and in the near future may prove the only havens for life on a fatally polluted planet.

The leap from terrestrial biospheres to bases on Mars and beyond, Mr. Sagan imagines, is not great, and ''once life gets into space using recycling technology, it will. . . . snap off the earthly umbilical cord.'' At that point, he continues grandiloquently, ''our planetary parent . . . could be crushed like a sunflower seed with no threat of violence to life as a whole.''

Mr. Sagan claims to be writing science fact, not fiction; however, he provides little proof to support his contentions. At his best when describing natural phenomena and stumping for a new ecological ethos, he engages in mere fatuity when promulgating his progressivist, New Age argument (''The pen I use to write belongs not to me but to the Earth, to the Earth writing a note to itself''), and he verges continually on teleology (global warming, he writes, may be the planet's way of ''ridding itself of excess humanity''). In a particularly muddled passage, Mr. Sagan compares the environmental ravages of industrialization to both cancer and pregnancy.

Throughout, ''Biospheres'' is devoid of socioeconomic analysis and lacking in humanity. Sadly absent from Mr. Sagan's biocentric and technophilic scenario is any consideration of the spiritual and esthetic dimensions of a future spent in artificial, climate controlled enclosures.
